data.title: King's Daughters
data.text:
This table is a list of King's Daughters, the immigrants who went to Quebec from 1663 to 1673, during a project to increase the population of the colony of New France when it became a royal colony.

This table is built automatically, links included. If the person married once, the link is to her family sheet. If she was single or married many times, the link is directed to the parents, even if only one union produced children. In the current version, all partners are indicated, even if it is a cancelled marriage contract.

General Statistics

Almost any Quebecer with old French roots has at least one King's Daughters in his/her ancestry, the question being : how many ? (usually, between 50 and 100). However, some Acadians who moved recently to Quebec may have a completely Acadian ancestry with not King's Daughters.

Background colors mean:

Green: indicates there are descendants after 1899 in the database.

Blue: indicates there is no descendant after 1899 in the database but living descendants may exist

Notes :

The column "Descendants" indicates the marriages in the complete database, where some genealogies are private.

11/2032 means 11 generations and 2032 marriages of descendants in the database (duplicates not filtered).

() indicates the most recent marriage in the database.

[] indicates the most recent marriage in completely female line in the database (for DNA analysis)

The column "Estimated Living Descendants in Quebec" is based on 100 genealogies from couples married in the province of QuÃ©bec in 1939 and 1940.
